title: Birth of the Solar System and Earth
description: The Solar System formed from a giant molecular cloud, and Earth was born during this period.
impact: This event marks the beginning of Earth's geological and biological evolution.

title: Oldest Moon Rocks
description: The oldest known rocks from the Moon, brought back by Apollo missions, date to around 4.48 billion years ago.
impact: These rocks provide valuable insights into the early history of the Moon and the Earth-Moon system.

title: Oldest Rocks Recognized on Earth
description: The oldest rocks on Earth have been dated to approximately 4.0 billion years, providing insight into early Earth conditions.
impact: These rocks are essential for understanding the formation of Earth's crust and early geological processes.

title: Oldest Recognizable Fossils of Single-Celled Bacteria
description: Fossils of single-celled bacteria, dating to around 3.5 billion years ago, mark the earliest evidence of life on Earth.
impact: These fossils provide the first evidence of life on Earth, helping to trace the origins of biology.

title: Oldest Recognizable Single-Celled Organisms with Nuclei
description: The first recognizable single-celled organisms with nuclei appeared around 1.5 billion years ago.
impact: This event represents the evolution of complex cells, laying the foundation for multicellular life.

title: Origin of Sexual Reproduction
description: Sexual reproduction likely emerged around 1 billion years ago, driving genetic diversity and evolution.
impact: The origin of sexual reproduction is a key step in increasing genetic diversity and evolutionary innovation.

title: First Multi-Celled Animals
description: The first multi-celled animals appeared around 700 million years ago, marking a key step in the evolution of complex life forms.
impact: The rise of multi-cellular organisms set the stage for the complex animals that followed, including humans.

title: First Animals with Hard Shells
description: The first animals with hard shells, such as trilobites, appeared around 540 million years ago during the Cambrian period.
impact: The evolution of hard shells protected organisms and allowed for the development of more complex ecosystems.

title: First Fish
description: The first fish appeared around 480 million years ago, marking a crucial step in the evolution of vertebrates.
impact: Fish are the ancestors of all vertebrates, including mammals, reptiles, and birds, making them pivotal in evolutionary history.

title: First Land Plants
description: The first land plants evolved around 420 million years ago, beginning the colonization of Earth's landmasses.
impact: Land plants played a key role in shaping Earth's atmosphere and ecosystems, making terrestrial life possible.

title: First Amphibians
description: Amphibians, the first vertebrates to live on land, evolved around 380 million years ago.
impact: Amphibians were crucial in the transition from aquatic to terrestrial life, influencing future vertebrate evolution.

title: First Reptiles
description: Reptiles, the first fully terrestrial vertebrates, emerged around 320 million years ago.
impact: Reptiles' adaptation to land environments allowed for the colonization of diverse ecosystems and laid the groundwork for mammals and birds.

title: Largest Mass Extinction in Earth's History
description: The Permian-Triassic extinction event, around 250 million years ago, was the largest mass extinction, wiping out 90% of species.
impact: This mass extinction reshaped life on Earth, paving the way for the rise of the dinosaurs and later mammals.

title: First Dinosaurs
description: Dinosaurs first appeared around 210 million years ago, becoming the dominant life forms during the Mesozoic era.
impact: Dinosaurs became the dominant terrestrial vertebrates, influencing ecosystems and evolutionary patterns for millions of years.

title: First Birds
description: Birds evolved from theropod dinosaurs around 160 million years ago, marking the rise of avian life forms.
impact: The evolution of birds marks a major shift in the Earth's ecosystems, leading to the vast diversity of modern bird species.

title: Mass Extinction, Including Dinosaurs
description: A mass extinction event occurred 66 million years ago, leading to the extinction of the dinosaurs and the rise of mammals.
impact: This event led to the decline of dinosaurs and opened ecological niches for mammals to evolve and diversify.

title: Early Hominids
description: Early hominids, ancestors of humans, appeared around 3-4 million years ago, laying the foundation for human evolution.
impact: The emergence of early hominids marks the beginning of human evolution, setting the stage for the development of modern humans.

title: Modern Ice Ages Begin
description: The modern ice ages began around 2 million years ago, shaping Earth's climate and ecosystems.
impact: The ice ages had profound impacts on global climate patterns and ecosystems, driving evolutionary changes and shaping human migration.

title: Advent of Agriculture and Civilization
description: Around 10,000 years ago, humans began cultivating crops, leading to the rise of civilizations and the modern world.
impact: The development of agriculture revolutionized human society, allowing for the establishment of permanent settlements and the rise of complex civilizations.
